awd_titl_txt: BPC-DP: Leveraging Institutional Data Collection and Analysis as an Entry to BPC Work: A Pilot Program to Support Emerging DEI Efforts
awd_abstract_narration:
Broadening participation in computing (BPC) is a national priority. However, the capacity of higher education institutions to monitor and report on BPC data is highly variable. Building on work that was successfully conducted through the BRAID initiative, a BPC effort at 15 undergraduate computing departments, this project engages three to five institutions that have had no or limited engagement with previous BPC initiatives. Efforts include collecting undergraduate computing enrollment and degree attainment (EDA) data disaggregated by gender and race/ethnicity, creating data visualizations to analyze departmental trends and patterns, and working closely with institutional partners to understand their BPC data and develop effective strategies for maintaining and reporting it. This project stands to inform change and data-driven decisions to improve BPC at the institutional-level and enhance the validity of BPC data that is provided to external stakeholders.

There is broad consensus on the critical necessity of robust data in addressing persistent participation gaps in computing. This project’s data collection process is intentionally designed to serve as an initial entry point into leveraging departmental data for BPC efforts by focusing on EDA patterns narrowly within the Computer Science major and more broadly across “All Computing” majors. The key outputs of this project include: 1) detailed, interactive data visualizations that depict trends by gender (e.g., women in computing), race/ethnicity (e.g., Black students in computing), and the combination of these identities (e.g., Black women in computing), and 2) one-on-one workshops with each participating institution to highlight key findings and guide participants to consider specific actions and interventions to address participation gaps. With an enhanced understanding of their BPC data and related trends, institutions can engage more meaningfully in other existing BPC efforts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Momentum: Accelerating Equity in Computing and Technology is a research group founded by Dr. Linda J. Sax and was co-led with Dr. Kathleen J. Lehman (until her departure in July 2024) in the School of Education & Information Studies at UCLA. From 2015 to 2021, the Momentum team studied the BRAID initiative. The initiative’s 15 computing departments committed to increasing participation of students from historically underrepresented groups, including women and Black, Latinx, and Indigenous students of all genders. As the research arm of the BRAID initiative, the UCLA team collected undergraduate computing enrollment and degree attainment (EDA) data, broken out by gender and race/ethnicity, to examine whether and to what extent BRAID institutions narrowed participation gaps. Through this project, we provided annual data visualizations to help BRAID departments track their year-to-year patterns and trends in enrollment and degree attainment for each institution. Having developed a streamlined data collection, analysis, and visualization process that directly supported and informed BPC efforts at BRAID institutions, we believed that these data visualizations could benefit other institutions in pursuit of BPC.

The overarching goal of this project was to engage computing departments that either have not previously been involved with or have not successfully leveraged their involvement in existing BPC efforts such as Northeastern University’s Center for Inclusive Computing (CIC) and/or the National Center for Women and Information Technology’s (NCWIT) Academic Alliance, among others. A strong understanding of institutional enrollment and degree attainment data is a foundational element of any BPC effort. By working with our team to gather and understand their enrollment and degree attainment data, participating schools gained valuable insights into their current computing department trends and patterns that can inform change at their institutions. At a broader scale, we envisioned this project as a pilot toward the first step in a longer term process of these and other institutions becoming more involved in BPC efforts. Momentum’s EDA data collection process aimed to better equip institutions to apply for and participate in programmatic BPC initiatives. In doing so, we aimed to ensure sustainable, meaningful engagement that prioritizes diversity, equity, and inclusion in computing.

Participating institutions provided their five most recent years (2018-2023) of enrollment and degree attainment data, broken out by gender and race. Our team cleaned and analyzed the submitted data using SPSS statistical software before uploading the data to Tableau to create visualizations. Two visualization decks (each with 13 visualizations) were created for each participating institution, one for their enrollment data and one for their degree attainment data. We then hosted a workshop for each institution where we shared their visualization decks, focusing on notable patterns and trends in their enrollment and degree attainment data as well as useful navigational tools offered by Tableau. The visualization files were shared with each institution after the workshop for their continued use.

Overall, we found that this project provided a useful tool for institutions to better understand the landscape of their computing enrollment and degree attainment. From the visualizations, we glean that each institution made strides in enrolling and matriculating a more diverse group of students, yet we also saw a hint of some plateauing in their enrollment and degree attainment in their most recent year. While we cannot attest to the cause of this plateauing or if it will continue in future years, it did provide institutions with insights into monitoring their progress. Logistically, our team found that many challenges and barriers ranging from limited personnel and expertise to data acquisition restrictions made it difficult for institutions to invest (money and time) in enrollment and degree attainment visualizations as a resource for leveraging their BPC efforts. As federal agencies who are interested in BPC efforts move forward, we recommend a strengthened investment in this type of data analysis and visualization that considers these challenges as tracking of computing-related EDA is an important part of informing change in computing and tech.

 


Last Modified: 12/16/2024
Modified by: Kathleen J Lehman
